awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: SURPASS: NSF SFS Unique Scholarship Program in Hardware and Systems Security
awd_abstract_narration:
There is an urgent need for a well-trained cybersecurity workforce in the government and private sectors. An effective cybersecurity education for our undergraduate and graduate students, using a well-designed curriculum, is essential to meet this need. The emergence of the Internet-of-Things, which promises an unprecedented number of devices, all connected to the Internet, makes the demand for cybersecurity education stronger than ever. This demand calls for not just an enhanced effort, but also a paradigm shift from traditional computer and information security education, which typically assumes that the hardware underlying the information systems is secure and trustworthy. Nonetheless, with a wide array of emerging attacks on hardware, that assumption is rapidly becoming invalid. Hence, there is a critical need to re-design our cybersecurity curriculum such that the nation's STEM student population is ready to take on future cybersecurity challenges. This scholarship program, called SURPASS, is a collaborative effort between two universities, University of Florida (UF) and Florida International University (FIU). Both universities serve diverse student populations, strong internationally-recognized hardware and systems security research programs, and extensive curricular offerings in cybersecurity, with the goal of addressing this need. Specifically, this program provides scholarships to encourage some of the best and brightest students in the state of Florida to pursue careers in hardware and systems security (HSS).

The SURPASS SFS program by UF and FIU uniquely involves training students on critical aspects of cybersecurity with a strong emphasis on practical hands-on learning in HSS, utilizing unique lab facilities. SURPASS prepares future cybersecurity practitioners and researchers with a holistic education and training in HSS. Key features of SURPASS are as follows: (1) a focus on hardware security and trust at all levels of hardware abstraction, from chips to printed circuit boards (PCBs) to systems; (2) a careful integration of HSS education into a complete cybersecurity curriculum to enable students to understand system security issues spanning multiple layers, from devices to networks to the cloud; (3) extensive hands-on training, a unique feature, which not only helps students understand the makeup of a complex system, but also stimulates their interest in exploring new attacks/defenses; (4) integration of continuous one-to-one student mentoring from recruitment to placement and a systematic tracking of student progress; and finally, (5) training of a highly-diverse student population leading to the creation of a diverse workforce leveraging the large percentage (81%) of minority students at FIU.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we established a CyberCorps: Scholarship for Service (SFS) program at Florida International University (FIU) jointly with University of Florida (UF) for undergraduate and graduate students interested in careers in hardware and systems security (HSS). Our program called SURPASS: NSF SFS Unique Scholarship Program in Hardware and Systems Security aimed at addressing the ever-growing critical need for well-trained security experts in diverse areas of computer security in government sectors that includes cyber physical systems (CPS) security, Internet of Things (IoT) security, hardware assurance, and information assurance. 

 

Our SFS program has provided a comprehensive ecosystem of HSS training including curricula changes, certificates, and labs, that produced multiple cohorts of SFS students strongly focusing on research and trained in various aspects of HSS. Specifically, our SFS program has successfully trained 23 FIU students and was able place them into various cybersecurity career paths in government. FIU SFS program has exceeded the initial goal of training 14 students by 9 students (64% increase). Given the expertise of the PIs, and the unique and engaging facilities at FIU, the student involvement in various security-centric research efforts has been a major focus of the SFS program. In particular, the FIU SFS students have successfully published their research in >36 technical papers/articles and generated more than 10 Patents (4 awarded, 6 pending) under supervision of their respective faculty mentors. Our efforts also produced 6 PhD SFS students at FIU and 5 MS theses. Even undergraduate (UG) students have been involved in different research activities as part of UG “individual research work” classes which were integrated into the curriculum as electives. In addition to the traditional curricular activities, we also emphasized obtaining government-accepted security certificates (e.g., CompTIA Security +) in our SFS programs. 9 FIU SFS scholars have received their security certificates after successfully passing their certification exams. FIU SFS scholars have received 9 awards/recognitions in different events/venues, including best demo/poster awards, outstanding UG, and graduate student awards from FIU President and Provost Offices. Moreover, our program offered training to SFS Scholars in many aspects of professional development, strengthening their skills in writing, presentation and teamwork. Finally, our program has generated outstanding outcomes in broadening the participation of the underrepresented minority students into cybersecurity, as 78% of our SFS students have been from underrepresented groups.

 

The recent CHIPS and Science Act also promotes on-shore microelectronics manufacturing supported by the development of a skilled, sustainable, and diverse workforce. This has also accentuated the critical need for future workforce trained in hardware and systems security. FIU SFS program has addressed this critical need through its unique SFS program focused on HSS. The students who were trained in our SFS program will have a long-lasting impact in different cybersecurity career paths serving government.
